nodes.bodyText: Consider adding a warning level log message when this is used so it can be identified if somehow invoked in non-test env's.  (This could also be done in the forceRegister methods instead.)
Do we need a way for tests to remove callbacks after test completion?

No, and removing them would break tests.
The callbacks are added with the initialization of the logging framework specific MDC class (with LogContextScopeListener.add()).  This only happens once per module.  Everything worked fine previously because CoreTracer was static and only created once per module.
With the changes in this PR, CoreTracer is created once per test class but the MDC initialization still only happens once per module.  Those callbacks need to be called on every CoreTracer instance.
In the future, if we have classloader isolation between test classes in the same module, the MDC class would be initialized multiple times, but the static installationCallbacks field would also be initialized multiple times.
tl;dr: the lifecycle of installationCallbacks needs to match the lifecycle of the MDC subclass which is static for now.
I'm not sure I understand this change... please elaborate.

The previous code had a static instance named TEST_LISTENER that implemented AgentBuilder.Listener and called onInstrumentationError and shouldTransformClass on subclasses of AgentTestRunner.
With this PR, AgentTestRunner implements AgentBuilder.Listener directly:
shouldTransformClass() -> onDiscovery()
onInstrumentationError() -> onError()
TEST_LISTENER previously threw  AbortTransfomationException when shouldTransformClass returned false.
The test for ContextTestInstrumentation.getName() + '$Incorrect' was moved to AgentTestRunner.  The incorrect api usage instrumentation errors were being picked up by more that just this particular test because of the change in the ordering of the test lifecycle.  If that wasn't the case, onInstrumentationError would have just been changed to onError.
Why is it necessary? I would expect the .class to be implicit now that this is groovy.
